front.div:
To understand the details of the homeotic systems that govern flower development in tomato and to establish the ground
rules for the judicious manipulation of this floral system, we have isolated the tomato AGAMOUS gene, designated TAGí,
and examined its developmental role in antisense and sense transgenic plants. The AGAMOUS gene of Arabidopsis is
necessary for the proper development of stamens and carpels and the prevention of indeterminate growth of the floral
meristem. Early in flower development, TAGí RNA accumulates uniformly in the cells fated to differentiate into stamens
and carpels and later becomes restricted to specific cell types within these organs. Transgenic plants that express TAGí
antisense RNA display homeotic conversion of third whorl stamens into petaloid organs and the replacement of fourth
whorl carpels with pseudocarpels bearing indeterminate floral meristems with nested perianth flowers. A complemen-
tary phenotype was observed in transgenic plants expressing the TAGl sense RNA in that first whorl sepals were converted
into mature pericarpic leaves and sterile stamens replaced the second whorl petals.
